Expectation1: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation1: The customer asks about the delivery status, while a delivery issue arises, such as a delayed or misplaced package
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The nun has a quiet afternoon and plans to spend time in personal spiritual reading and contemplation.
Story: I had planned my afternoon carefully, eager for the rare quiet hours in my small room at the convent. My Bible and journal waited on the desk, sunlight slanting through the window, promising peace. But just as I settled in, my phone buzzed—work. A customer’s message popped up, asking about a package that, I realized with a sinking feeling, had been delayed at the depot. As a delivery person, I was expected to respond quickly, politely, and with solutions, even when I had none. My fingers hovered over the screen, torn. The convent expected me to be present, to set aside worldly distractions and focus on spiritual reflection. Yet my other job demanded immediate attention, professionalism, and calm reassurance. I felt the tension coil in my chest—if I answered, I’d break the silence I so rarely found; if I ignored it, I’d fail a customer and risk my job. The two worlds pressed in, each asking for all of me, and I sat there, phone in hand, heart pulled in two directions.
